posted_at: {'date': '2025-06-20 18:30:07', 'relative': '3 days ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1750437007458}
text:
‚ÄúIf you want to feel better, blame others. 
If you want to get better, blame yourself.‚Äù 
‚Äì Alex Hormozi

This clip hit me hard ‚Äî because it aligns perfectly with one of my favorite leadership books of all time: Extreme Ownership by Jocko Willink and Leif Babin.

Here‚Äôs the uncomfortable truth:

üõë Victim mindset kills performance

üõ† Ownership mindset builds teams that win

When something breaks down in our agency ‚Äî

I don‚Äôt ask ‚Äúwho messed up?‚Äù

I ask:
‚Üí ‚ÄúWhat could I have done better?‚Äù
‚Üí ‚ÄúWhere did I drop the ball as a leader?‚Äù

Extreme Ownership dedicates an entire chapter to this:

There are no bad teams. Only bad leaders.

Bad leaders deflect.

Great leaders absorb.

They turn every failure into feedback.

At CoEfficient Labs, this isn‚Äôt just a leadership book on a shelf.

It‚Äôs baked into our culture ‚Äî from growth hackers to video editors to software engineers.

We don‚Äôt point fingers.

We point inward.

Because when the leadership takes ownership‚Ä¶

the whole team starts rowing in the same direction.

üéß Watch the full video (it‚Äôs only 60 seconds) ‚Äî it might change how you lead this week.

üìö Shoutout to Alex Hormozi, Jocko Willink, & Leif Babin ‚Äî your work shaped how I lead today.

‚ù§Ô∏è

posted_at: {'date': '2025-06-16 18:30:06', 'relative': '1 week ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1750091406899}
text:
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing more fun than saying yes.
But most of the job‚Ä¶ is saying no.‚Äù
Rick Smith, Co-Founder of Crosscut Ventures

Let that sink in üëá

VC looks glamorous from the outside.

Raise a fund. Write checks. Build a portfolio of hot startups.

But according to Rick ‚Äî that‚Äôs not the job.

The job is passing.

Sticking to your strike zone.

Saying no when everything in you wants to say yes.

In our latest episode of Demo Day, Rick broke down the 4 things every great deal needs:
‚úÖ Market
‚úÖ Product
‚úÖ Team
‚úÖ Valuation

Here‚Äôs the wild part‚Ä¶

Even if a company is GREAT ‚Äî

if the entry price is wrong, the investment doesn‚Äôt work.

It‚Äôs possible to back a unicorn‚Ä¶

and still lose money.

That‚Äôs why Rick plays the long game.

And when he misses a winner?

He doesn‚Äôt second guess ‚Äî as long as he followed his process.

üéß Full episode is now live. 

üì• Link in the comments.

text:
We showed up to hire students‚Ä¶ 
and left with leads.
At Loyola Marymount University‚Äôs career expo, we had one goal:

‚Üí Meet great talent.

But what we didn‚Äôt expect?

The real value wasn‚Äôt just in the students‚Ä¶

It was in the other tables:
- Recruiters
- Sales leaders
- Executives

All from companies we could actually help.

So we did what we always do:
- Talked to everyone
- Got the emails
- Shared what makes us different

No fancy booth.

No hard sell.

Just authentic connection.

Because whether it‚Äôs a job fair, a lunch meeting, or a yoga studio (yep, met someone from YogaWorks)...

‚Üí It‚Äôs all a stage if you treat it like one.

If you want new business, new intros, new growth‚Äî

You can‚Äôt wait for the ‚Äúright moment.‚Äù

You need to make the moment.

‚ù§Ô∏è

posted_at: {'date': '2025-06-11 18:30:04', 'relative': '1 week ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1749659404803}
text:
VCs pass on countless deals throughout their careers‚Ä¶
And inevitably, some of those passes become massive wins.
Here are the 3 questions Rick Smith asks himself when a pass wins big:

1. Did we even see the deal?
- If not, why not? Was it in our network? In our market? That‚Äôs a sourcing gap.

2. Was it in our strike zone?
- Right stage, right sector, right founder? If not, maybe it just wasn‚Äôt a fit.

3. Did we follow our process?
- If yes, then even a miss is a win. Because consistency > regret.

üí° The takeaway: Don‚Äôt obsess over what you didn‚Äôt do.

Obsess over having a repeatable process ‚Äî and sticking to it.

üé• Full Demo Day Podcast episode with Rick Smith (Co-Founder of Crosscut Ventures) in the comments!

Conferences can be overwhelming as f***!
Here‚Äôs how to get the most value from themüëáüèª

1. Map your plan BEFORE the event
2. Know which ppl you absolutely want to talk with
3. Find brands you can partner with
4. Even if you don‚Äôt sell ‚Äî awareness breeds awareness!
5. Get over your fear ‚Äî say f*** it ‚Äî and introduce yourself!
